reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Love the book
reviews.reviewText: Great writer I reread this book twice

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 3, 2023
reviews.reviewText: I loved everything about this book! It was a wonderful read, and a great addition for my book collection. Fantastic author!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 6, 2023
reviews.reviewText: Calan, the laird of Kilcairn, is out for a swim in the loch when a thief tries to make off with his plaid. He gave chase and managed to catch the offender by tackling them to the ground. It’s only when the boy is in his arms that Calan realizes it’s not a boy at all, it a young woman…. And she’s naked.Seeing that she is suffering from injuries, he takes the mystery woman through a secret passage into his keep to get her the healing and rest she needs.Allissaid was kidnapped by her clans enemy and forced into a marriage despite being unconscious. She manages to escape , even going so far as to risk death to do so. But after trying to steal a plaid, and failing, she wakes up in an unknown room with a man sitting on top of her while a woman tends to her injuries.Not knowing if they are friend or foe, she feigns memory loss. However, the more time she spends with Calan, the more she falls for him and her lies are chipped away.Random change of pace with a nice historical romance of the Scottish variety! I used to be heavily into these stories and this one is no exception! Having had recently read the book before this in the series, I saw it was for sale and purchased it!I love being able to get a glimpse into the past and how life was during that time. It’s nice to see that while most men in this era view women as property, not all did. Some were loving and gentle men that are still rare to find today.I liked seeing how Calan was with Allissaid, watching a tenderness that even his mother and sister weren’t aware he had. I do wish that we would have gotten to see him as a leader, but seeing as the majority of the book takes place in his bedroom with Allissaid hidden away, it does make sense why that aspect is missing.A decent read that I did enjoy but wasn’t super in love with.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 27, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars A great addition to the series!!
reviews.reviewText: In Her Highlander's Bed by Lynsay Sands is a darling character-driven historical romance with an ensemble of lovable characters. I have read many books within this series and while they tend to follow the same template they are always entertaining: delivering endearing protagonists, humorous escapades, witty banter, and intriguing drama, along with atrocious and misogynistic villains. Though this story is slower-paced than I would have preferred, it's a great addition to the Highland Brides series and includes some of my favorite romantic tropes.Clever and wholesome heroine - Allissaid MacFarlaneShy and considerate hero with a protective nature - Calan Campbell, Laird of KilcairnDual POV***** SAFETY AND CONTENT SPOILERS BELOW ***********************************************************Tropes: damsel in distress, injury, forced proximity, hidden/mistaken identity, one bed, honorable marriageContent Warning:Light spice, descriptive - vanilla - virgin hViolence, murder, kidnapping, assault and attempted SA

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 20, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Humor and sword fights!
reviews.reviewText: There's a subtle Humor to this series. The characters are very good and are individuals. And of coarse pitting the good guys against the bad guys with the good guys winning with no angst. Pretty much enjoy all her books!!!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2023
reviews.reviewText: Merch idea: Keep Calm and Lynsay Sands. If a Sands' Historical Romance can't fix what ails you - consider 911. In Her Highlander's Bed is Allissaid's story, the younger sister of Claray MacFarlane from Highland Wolf (Book 10). MacNaughton (or MacNaughty) is still casing the MacFarlane clan for a bride, and after a mental game of Eeny, meeny, miny, moe, he lands on the second oldest daughter. Powerful clans are rallying against MacNaughton and his cohorts. Unfortunately, it was not in time to save Allissaid from his despicable hands. In Her Highlander's Bed is an exceptional addition to the Highland Bride series!KrisWhiskey & Wit Book Reviews

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 13, 2023
reviews.reviewText: Calan Campbell is a Laird of his clan, but he’s not expecting to discover a beaten Allissaid MacFarlane trying to steal his plaid while he goes swimming.Allissaid is grateful that the Campbells help her in her hour of need, but she has a Laird with nefarious intentions after her and her family, and she needs to warn them…Allissaid MacFarlane is a cousin to the Buchanans that form the vast majority of the heroes in this series, and her sister Claray was the heroine in the previous book. It’s actually a good idea to have read Highland Wolf before this one, since this does continue the story arc that began in that one.We do have a couple of Buchanan cameos too, for fans of the series, but this book is a bit more serious than most of the others than precede it. There are a couple of smile and chuckle worthy moments, but Allissaid’s story begins with a harsh note.It’s a surprisingly entertaining book, given that the vast majority of it takes place in one room, and it doesn’t lack for action or excitement. The hero is typical of Sands’ historicals, strong and brave and inclined towards action, while the heroine is amusingly naïve (but not afraid to protect herself or those she loves). She’s definitely resourceful, as is amply shown at the start of the book.It’s a good read, and Buchanan fans will enjoy the small glimpses of that family, as well as enjoy the new MacFarlane ladies who seem to be just as interesting.An enjoyable read for highland historical romance fans.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 20, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars Average for this series
reviews.reviewText: Pretty average for the series, a little tamer than the earlier books and not as amusing as some but overall a good entry. I liked Calan and Allissaid for the entire book. I was never once angry at or disappointed with either of them, which has not always been the case with these Highlanders and their brides.I was disappointed this book didn’t pick up on what I thought was the start of a story about one or two of the McKay daughters at the end of the previous installment. Ross and Annabel are my favorite characters in the series. I was looking forward to seeing more of them.

reviews.reviewTitle: Yeah!!!!! But who shot the Arrows?
reviews.reviewText: Great end for the villain! But is the next story going to tell us who shot the arrow at the Campbell and killed his sister's betrothed? Will it be Inghinn & Alick story to solve that puzzle.....I can't wait to find out.....
Easy to read, better entertainment than have no entertainment but boring. Didn’t really touch me

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 29, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: Another great book in the series.
reviews.reviewText: Another brilliant book in the Highland Brides book. I now have bought and have read all 11 books and have enjoyed each one. Allaisand and Calan were great characters and it was nice to read of previous characters. Another great book from Lynsay.
I am hoping there is another book in this series. I want to see Alick find a wife. This can't be the end. Excellent series enjoyed them all

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 25, 2023
reviews.reviewText: The h is a relative of the Buchanan brothers and sister to the h of #10 book. The H is another convenient Laird who she has never met before yet knows his mother quite well. He rescues her as she attempts to steal his plaid when he was swimming in the loch. She is battered and bruised from being kidnapped and almost raped. He hides her and the family look after her as she recovers. He compromises her and then marries her.This book is feeble and dreadfully written. If it was a first novel am sure the editor would have laughed and tossed it back to the author. Don't know what is going on with Sands but the deterioration is plumeting rapidly! The long long explanations were not even pleasant prose, just tedious, tireseome and utterly unnecessary. Very repetitive and some of the phrases like "hard as a dead hen" were bizarre and too colloquial.Cannot recommend and wont bother to read any more of this series. Shame that.
